Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Looking at the traces: Case 1: RA VF AE RMI VF AD SC AC Case 2: RA VF AE AD SC AC Case 3: RA VF AE RMI RMI VF AD SC AC

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Common patterns: 1. All cases start with RA 2. Then VF 3. Then AE 4. After AE, theres either Directly to AD Case 2 Or enter a loop involving RMI and possibly repeating VF Cases 1 and 3

Name: Hypothesis Generation - NE
Text: If I model the part after AE as * ( AD, -> ( RMI, VF ) )

Name: Validation - NE
Text: No, that doesnt look right because In Case 2: we just do AD exit immediately In Case 1: we do RMI, VF, then AD In Case 3: we do RMI, RMI, VF, then AD if the loop is * ( X, Y ), the behavior is 1. Execute X 2. Either stop, or execute Y then X again

Name: Backtracking - IND
Text: Let me reconsider the loop structure. The operator * (A, B) means: execute A, then either you exit the loop, or you execute B and then A again

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: After AE, we either go to AD directly Case 2, OR We enter a cycle of request missing info and re-validate, and then go to AD. But in Case 3, we have two RMIs but only one VF at the end

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: The pattern after AE seems to be zero or more RMIs, then optionally VF, then AD? But if zero RMIs, we dont want VF Case 2. If one or more RMIs, we want VF Cases 1 and 3. So AE then X ( AD, -> ( RMI+, VF, AD ) )

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: -> ( AE, X ( tau, -> ( RMI+, VF ) ), AD ) means - AE, then tau or RMI+ VF, then AD. If tau: AE AD Case 2 If RMI+ VF: AE RMI+ VF AD Cases 1 and 3 This looks correct

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: * (RMI, tau) generates one or more RMIs. Execute RMI Either exit giving one RMI, or execute tau then RMI again giving RMIRMI

Name: Validation - PE
Text: For Case 2: AE tau AD = AE AD. Good. For Case 1: AE RMI VF AD. Good. For Case 3: AE RMI RMI VF AD. Good. Perfect

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: The full tree: -> ( RA, VF, AE, X ( tau, -> ( * ( RMI, tau ), VF ) ), AD, SC, AC )
